questions.text: A 55-year-old woman comes to the physician 10 days after noticing a mass in her left breast while bathing. She is concerned that it is breast cancer because her sister was diagnosed with breast cancer 3 years ago at 61 years of age. Menopause occurred 6 months ago. She has smoked 2 packs of cigarettes daily for 30 years. She took an oral contraceptive for 20 years. Current medications include hormone replacement therapy and a calcium supplement. On examination, a 2.5-cm, hard, nontender mass is palpated in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. Examination of the right breast and axillae shows no abnormalities. Mammography shows an irregular mass with microcalcifications and oil cysts. A core biopsy specimen shows foam cells and multinucleated giant cells. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

In patients with breast cancer, neoadjuvant chemotherapy can reduce the size of the tumor before surgery to allow for greater preservation of normal tissue (e.g., by performing a lumpectomy instead of mastectomy). This patient, however, most likely has fat necrosis of the breast and, therefore, chemotherapy is not indicated.

B) INCORRECT:

Trastuzumab is an adjuvant therapy for biopsy-proven ERBB2+ breast cancer. Although breast cancer will appear as an irregular mass with microcalcifications on mammography, it tends to have a spiculated appearance without oil cysts. Furthermore, biopsy would show proliferation of cells that invade through the basement membrane, not foam cells and giant cells.

C) CORRECT:

Fat necrosis of the breast is a benign breast condition most commonly caused by trauma to the breast. Patients may present with examination and radiological findings that mimic malignancy (e.g., irregular borders, skin retraction), and biopsy is typically performed to confirm the diagnosis. Fat necrosis does not increase the risk of breast cancer and, therefore, reassurance and follow-up in accordance with breast cancer screening guidelines is appropriate. If fat necrosis causes significant discomfort, pain, or distortion of the breast, surgery may be considered.

D) INCORRECT:

Lumpectomy with axillary staging (i.e., sentinel lymph node biopsy) is a treatment option for patients with a solitary malignant tumor localized to one breast quadrant. Patients who undergo lumpectomy usually require adjuvant radiation to reduce the risk of recurrence. This patient, however, most likely has fat necrosis of the breast and, therefore, lumpectomy with axillary staging is not indicated.

E) INCORRECT:

Anastrozole is an adjuvant therapy for postmenopausal women with biopsy-proven, hormone-receptor-sensitive breast cancer. Although breast cancer will appear as an irregular mass with microcalcifications on mammography, it tends to have a spiculated appearance without oil cysts. Also, biopsy would show proliferation of cells that invade through the basement membrane, not foam cells and giant cells.

F) INCORRECT:

Tamoxifen is an adjuvant therapy for women with biopsy-proven, hormone-receptor-sensitive breast cancer. Although breast cancer will appear as an irregular mass with microcalcifications on mammography, it tends to have a spiculated appearance without oil cysts. Also, biopsy would show proliferation of cells that invade through the basement membrane, not foam cells and giant cells.

G) INCORRECT:

Modified radical mastectomy is indicated for patients with biopsy-proven breast cancer that has spread to the axillary lymph nodes. This patient, however, most likely has fat necrosis of the breast and, therefore, mastectomy is not indicated.

H) INCORRECT:

Wide excision is indicated for phyllodes tumors because of their high rate of recurrence and potential for malignancy. A core biopsy specimen of a phyllodes tumor would show a leaf-like structure with papillary projections of epithelium-lined stroma, not foam cells and giant cells, the presence of which indicates fat necrosis of the breast. Excision may sometimes be considered in patients with fat necrosis of the breast who develop significant pain, discomfort, or distortion of the breast.

I) INCORRECT:

Simple mastectomy is indicated for patients with biopsy-proven breast cancer without spread to the axillary lymph nodes, and in those who do not meet criteria for breast-conserving surgery (e.g., contraindications to adjuvant radiation, > 1 tumor in separate breast quadrant). Although breast cancer will appear as an irregular mass with microcalcifications on mammography, it tends to have a spiculated appearance without oil cysts. Also, biopsy would show proliferation of cells that invade through the basement membrane, not foam cells and giant cells.
questions.hint: The presence of oil cysts on mammography suggests fat necrosis of the breast. Foam cells and multinucleated giant cells on biopsy confirm the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman comes to the physician a week after noticing a lump in her left breast. Three months ago, she was discharged from the hospital after treatment of multiple injuries sustained in a motor vehicle collision. Her only medication is an oral contraceptive. Her mother died of ovarian cancer. Examination shows a 2.5-cm, nontender mass in the upper outer quadrant of the left breast. Mammography shows a circumscribed radiolucent lesion with a rim of peripheral calcification. A photomicrograph of tissue from a biopsy of the mass is shown. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the breast swelling?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Thrombophlebitis of superficial veins of the breast (Mondor disease) can occur secondary to trauma. However, it would manifest as a tender, palpable superficial cord on the anterolateral surface of the breast and not as the painless lump seen here. Mammography, though not typically done in Mondor disease, would show a superficial tubular hypodense lesion. A biopsy would show a thrombosed vein and acute inflammatory infiltrate, none of which are seen here.

B) INCORRECT:

Stimulation of estrogen receptors is the underlying cause for the development of fibroadenoma, fibrocystic breast changes, and ER-positive breast cancer. All three of these conditions may present with a painless breast lump and calcifications on mammography, as seen in this patient. However, a fibroadenoma would show proliferation of glandular and stromal tissue on histopathology, while fibrocystic breast changes often cause nipple discharge, show numerous small cysts on mammography, and appear as proliferation of small ductules and acini in lobules on histopathology. Breast cancer is also unlikely because it would appear as an ill-defined mass with irregular microcalcifications on mammography, and cells with features of malignant transformation (e.g., hyperchromatism, mitotic figures) in the ducts or lobules on biopsy.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of breast tissue (H&E stain; 200x magnification)

Compressed glandular spaces, i.e., epithelial component of fibroadenoma (green overlay) and stromal component of fibroadenoma (red overlay), are visible.

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

C) INCORRECT:

Defective DNA repair is the underlying cause of hereditary breast cancer syndromes (e.g., BRCA1 or BRCA2 mutations, Lynch syndrome). Breast cancer can manifest as a painless breast lump and this patient has a high risk of developing breast cancer based on her age and family history of ovarian cancer. However, breast cancer would typically appear on mammography as an ill-defined mass with irregular microcalcifications and not as the circumscribed radiolucent lesion seen here. Moreover, cells with features of malignant transformation (e.g., hyperchromatism, mitotic figures, nuclear pleomorphism) would have been present in the ducts or lobules on biopsy.
Image Description:

Photomicrograph of a surgical sample of breast tissue (H&E stain, low magnification)

An area of sclerosis (light purple) is visible in the center of the invasive ductal carcinoma (dark purple).

Click on the Smartzoom button to view the entire specimen through a virtual microscope.

D) INCORRECT:

Obstruction of lactiferous ducts can result in a palpable breast lump due to breast abscess, a complication of mastitis. Breast abscess typically manifests as a tender breast lump with signs of inflammation (erythema, warmth, and tenderness) in lactating women. This patient's lump, however, is nontender, and she is not lactating. Mammography of breast abscess, though not typically performed, would show a heterogenic mass without calcification, in contrast to the calcification seen here. Biopsy would show an acute inflammatory infiltrate of neutrophils and cellular debris (liquefactive necrosis).

E) CORRECT:

Release of cytoplasmic triglycerides causes fat necrosis of the breast, which typically occurs following trauma, such as that sustained by this patient. Trauma damages adipocytes in breast tissue, spilling lipase and triglycerides into the interstitium. Triglycerides are then broken down by lipase into free fatty acids that bind with calcium to form calcium salts (saponification). The resulting inflammatory process walls off the injury as an oil cyst surrounded by necrotic, anucleate adipocytes; foam cells; and other inflammatory cells, as in the biopsy here. Fat necrosis of the breast can resemble malignancy on physical examination (painless lump) and/or imaging (calcifications), often making histological confirmation necessary.

questions.text: A 48-year-old woman presents with a new, palpable breast lump she noticed 2 weeks ago. She was in a minor car accident 1 month prior, causing a seatbelt injury to her left breast. Examination reveals a firm, irregular, 2-cm mass in the upper outer quadrant with mild skin retraction. A mammogram shows a spiculated mass with coarse calcifications, prompting a biopsy. The histopathologic findings of this patient's lesion are a direct result of which of the following processes?

choices.text: Biphasic proliferation of both glandular and stromal fibrous tissue
Cystic dilation of terminal ducts and prominent stromal fibrosis
Proliferation of malignant epithelial cells from the terminal duct-lobular unit
Saponification of fatty acids and infiltration by lipid-laden macrophages
Infiltration of plasma cells and lymphocytes within the mammary ducts

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Biphasic proliferation of both glandular and stromal fibrous tissue is the characteristic histopathology of a fibroadenoma. Fibroadenomas are typically well-circumscribed, mobile, non-tender masses and are not associated with skin retraction, spiculated margins on mammography, or a history of trauma.

B) INCORRECT:

Cystic dilation of terminal ducts and prominent stromal fibrosis describe fibrocystic changes, a common benign condition. Fibrocystic changes typically manifest as multiple, often bilateral, tender masses that may fluctuate with the menstrual cycle. They do not typically form a single, firm, irregular mass with skin retraction following trauma.

C) INCORRECT:

Proliferation of malignant epithelial cells from the terminal duct-lobular unit describes the pathophysiology of invasive ductal or lobular carcinoma. While the clinical findings of a firm, irregular mass with skin retraction and a spiculated appearance on mammography are highly suspicious for malignancy, the preceding history of direct trauma is the classic etiology for a different, benign process.

D) CORRECT:

Saponification of fatty acids and infiltration by lipid-laden macrophages describes the pathophysiology of breast fat necrosis, a benign inflammatory process most commonly caused by trauma. Damage to adipocytes releases triglycerides, which are hydrolyzed into fatty acids. These fatty acids combine with calcium in a process called saponification, forming insoluble salts that appear as calcifications on mammography. The inflammatory response involves the recruitment of lipid-laden macrophages (foam cells) to phagocytize the necrotic fatty material. Over time, this process leads to fibrosis and scarring, which can clinically and radiographically mimic breast cancer by causing a firm, irregular, spiculated mass with skin retraction. A biopsy confirms the diagnosis, and management is typically observation.

E) INCORRECT:

Infiltration of plasma cells and lymphocytes within the mammary ducts describes mammary duct ectasia or periductal mastitis, which are inflammatory conditions. While they can cause a palpable mass and skin changes, they are often associated with nipple discharge and are not typically initiated by direct blunt trauma to the breast parenchyma.
questions.hint: The history of direct trauma to the breast is the most important clue to the diagnosis, which presents as a cancer mimic on both physical examination and mammography.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presents for follow-up after a core needle biopsy of a new left breast lump. She has a history of stage I estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer treated two years ago with lumpectomy and radiation therapy. Physical examination shows a 1.5-cm firm, irregular, non-tender mass adjacent to her surgical scar. Imaging shows a spiculated mass with coarse rim calcifications. A core needle biopsy confirms fat necrosis with no evidence of malignancy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Observation with routine annual surveillance mammography

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Breast MRI is a highly sensitive imaging tool used for high-risk screening or for further evaluation of indeterminate findings after mammography and ultrasound. In this case, a definitive benign diagnosis has already been established through a core needle biopsy, resolving the diagnostic uncertainty. Therefore, obtaining an MRI would not add useful information or change management.

B) CORRECT:

The most appropriate management for a patient with fat necrosis of the breast, a benign inflammatory process that is a common sequela of breast surgery and radiation, is to reassure the patient and have her return to her standard post-treatment surveillance schedule. This typically involves annual surveillance mammography to monitor for any new or concerning changes in the breast. Although its clinical and mammographic features (firm, irregular, spiculated mass) can mimic malignancy, the core needle biopsy has definitively ruled out cancer recurrence. Once a benign diagnosis is established and is concordant with imaging, no further intervention is required for the fat necrosis itself.

C) INCORRECT:

Tamoxifen is an anti-estrogen agent used for the treatment and risk reduction of estrogen receptor-positive breast cancer. Fat necrosis is a benign, non-hormonal inflammatory condition resulting from tissue injury. Tamoxifen has no role in the management of fat necrosis.

D) INCORRECT:

Short-interval follow-up imaging is recommended for findings that are deemed probably benign (BI-RADS 3). This patient's lesion was initially suspicious enough to warrant a biopsy. Now that a definitive benign diagnosis has been established via biopsy, the finding is no longer considered probably benign, but is confirmed as benign. Therefore, short-interval follow-up is not indicated, and she can resume routine annual screening.

E) INCORRECT:

An excisional biopsy is a surgical procedure to remove the entire mass. This would be considered if the core needle biopsy was inconclusive or discordant with suspicious imaging findings. Since the core biopsy provided a definitive benign diagnosis of fat necrosis, performing a more invasive surgical procedure is unnecessary and exposes the patient to avoidable risks.
